section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Alphabet Cards (Cc, Dd), Cat Has a Cake, Dinosaurs Can, drawing and writing supplies

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read Ming Goes to School. We saw the letter c in the word castle and the letter d in the word old.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Teach Cc Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for letters Cc. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase C. The letter C makes the /k/ sound you hear in the word car. This is lowercase c. The letter c makes the /k/ sound you hear in cat.

Teach Dd Alphabet Cards Show the Alphabet Cards for the letterDd. Say the letter aloud and have children repeat. This is uppercase D. The letter D makes the /d/ sound you hear in the word duck. This is lowercase d. The letter d makes the /d/ sound you hear in dog.
Explain the Activity Share Cat Has a Cake. Today we will read about the letter Cc. Then we will read a book about the letter Dd .
Read Read aloud Cat Has a Cake and use the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Tap your nose when you hear a word that begins with the /k/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Read Read aloud Dinosaurs Can and use the following prompt.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Clap when you hear a word that begins with the /d/ sound.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Model writing uppercase and lowercase letters Cc and Dd. Provide drawing and writing supplies. Guide children in practicing forming their letters.

As you read Cat Has a Cake, stop at each word that begins with the letter Cc. Have children say /k/ and the word that begins with Cc. Repeat with Dinosaurs Can and the letter Dd. Some children will benefit from tracing letters in trays of salt or sand.

For a challenge, after reading each story, ask children try to recall all the words that begin with the target sound and letter. Then invite children to name any other words they know that begin with that letter and sound.

Some words have only one sound difference between them (for example, “dip” and “deep.”) Knowing beforehand that some minimal pairs may be difficult for a specific language group will guide you in giving more support to those children who need help.

Children who struggle to maintain attention may need reminders about the sound they are listening for. Before reading each page in the alphabet books, take a moment to remind children what sound they are listening for.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we read a story called Ming Goes to School and saw how she played with her friends at school.
When we want to play with others, we can use our words to help us. We can ask to join the other children or we can ask other children to join us.

Now, we’re going to practice joining a group at play. I’m going to choose children to pretend they are playing. One child will not be in the group. If you are not in the group, you will ask if you can play, too.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Set Up Ask all the children but one to pretend. The one child will the ask to join the group. Say to the group: Pretend you’re building a city with blocks. Children should actively pretend they are building.
Ask Invite one child to ask to join the group. Help with examples, such as:

ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted.ac_teacher-speaking: “That’s a great city. Can I add a train track to your city?”

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Extend Guide children as they take turns asking to join a group. Have groups pretend they are having a tea party, being pirates, playing in the snow, setting the table for dinner, and shopping in a store. Continue until each child has had one or two turns at asking to join the group.

Talk About Joining In Guide a discussion to help children see that asking others when you want to play is one way of joining in. Point out that another good way to join is just by playing side by side. Talk about times when they might just join in and play side by side, such as in the Creativity Station, the ABC Center, and the Writer’s Corner.
Some children may have difficulty when trying to think of what to say to join the group. Encourage those children to just say, “Can I play, too?”

Ask: What should you do when a new friend joins your playing and has new ideas? Help children see that they are part of a group and should listen to the ideas of others. Point out that playing is more fun when everyone feels like their ideas are important.

Begin by asking children to say, “Can I play, too?” in their home language. Then review any vocabulary related to the play scenarios that will be helpful to any child who wants to use more language when asking to join in. Be sensitive to cultural differences that might make some children hesitant.

Some children may find it difficult to engage in pretend play with a group. If anyone is having difficulty joining in the pretend, suggest what role that child might play or what that child might do to enhance the pretending.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials Activity Cards, paper, art supplies

ac_teacher-speaking.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we reread Ming Goes to School and talked about the things Ming does every day at school.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Now we are going to sing about things some children do every day at school.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Invite children to join you as you sing these lyrics to the tune of “This is the Way We Go to School.” “This is the way we paint at school, paint at school, paint at school. This is the way we paint at school, when we’re in our classroom.” Have children pantomime the activity.
Then hold up the picture of the children painting and ask: What do children do at school every day?
Ask Show each Activity Card and ask the question on the back of the card, offering extra support or challenge as needed.
Extend Use the last question on the back of the card to help make connections about school routines. Then sing the verse about painting at school.
Repeat Continue until all the cards have been used and a new verse has been sung about each: play, pretend, build, rest, and draw .

Talk About Things Children Do Every Day (Routines) Ask: Which of these things do we do in our class every day? Remind children that sometimes they are just like Ming and the children in her class, because there are things they do every day at school. If there is time, have children draw a picture of themselves doing an everyday thing.
Before children try to respond to the question, point out clues in picture. Then ask the question and use the support to help children form the sentence that answers the question.

After children determine the activity on each card, challenge them to tell where in their classroom the activity takes place. Also, ask children to name all the materials involved in doing the activity.

Multilingual learners may be hesitant to sing the song or not be familiar with the song. Take time before the activity to teach the song, so children can feel comfortable joining in as each new verse is added.

Children with fine motor developmental issues may struggle to pick cards from a pile. However, allowing children the time they need to pick up and hold the cards themselves can help them develop hand-eye coordination and finger dexterity.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Gather Materials The “Our School Rules” poster, a paper bag containing a toy train, a doll, a musical triangle, a bell, a sponge, and a get-well card.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: Today we talked about rules and read the Big Chart of Big Ideas.

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Explain the Activity Now, let’s see how well you know the rules!
section-block.ac_teacher-card-teacher_talk_bulleted: One of you will choose an object from the paper bag.
Then you can decide if the object is something you can use when following one or more than one of the school rules.
section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Model Without looking, pull the triangle from the bag. Read through the chart and ask: When can we use this triangle? Establish with children that we can use the triangle to listen to when someone plays it, and we can take turns using it.
Choose Ask one child to reach in and pull an object from the bag.
Match Then ask the child to match the object to one of the pictures on the chart. Invite other children to help with ideas for matching and telling how to use the object.
Extend Continue having children take turns matching the objects until all the objects have been matched.

ac_teacher-card-body.ac_teacher-speaking: What rules did we see Ming following in Ming Goes to School?

section-block.ac_teacher-card-body: Allow children time to go through the story, working as a group to identify rules they see in action. Any reasonable answer is acceptable.

If children need help in relating the objects to the rules, ask yes/no questions to guide them. For example, show the doll and ask, Is this something we can share? Is it something we can clean up and put away when we are finished using it?
Point to each rule on the Big Chart and ask, How are these rules related? Give this example: If children don’t listen to the teacher, they may do something unsafe. Ask children for other examples.

Preview the names of the items in the bag, so that when children pull out an item they know its name and can concentrate on making the match to the chart. You may need to encourage their thinking by saying, I see you have a triangle. A triangle is something we
.

Some children may have difficulty waiting their turn as items are pulled from the bag and discussed. You may want to give those children objects from the bag to hold to reassure them that their turns are coming.
